description.plain:
Terrence Thornton (born May 13, 1977), better known by his stage name Pusha T, is an American hip hop recording artist from Virginia Beach, Virginia. He served as the President of Kanye West’s G.O.O.D Music label from 2015-2022.

Pusha-T entered the game in 1999 with his brother No Malice (Gene Thornton) as Clipse on “The Funeral” from Exclusive Audio Footage. While the album was scrapped, this didn’t faze the pair, who went on to release Lord Willin', Hell Hath No Fury, and Till The Casket Drops in the space of seven years. In 2009, No Malice announced he had become a born-again Christian and couldn’t rap about his former lifestyle any longer. This forced Pusha to go solo.

He was invited to attend Kanye West’s My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy sessions in Hawaii in 2010 and later signed to West’s G.O.O.D. Music imprint. In November of 2015, Pusha-T was appointed by Kanye West to be the new President of G.O.O.D. Music.

Since being signed to G.O.O.D Music, T released Fear of God, Fear of God II: Let Us Pray, Wrath of Caine, and My Name Is My Name. His sophomore solo album, titled Darkest Before Dawn was released on December 18, 2015. In 2018, he released his critically acclaimed 3rd studio album DAYTONA, which was executive produced by Kanye West.

Pusha T has described his music as being  “high taste level, luxury, street hip hop [that’s] lyric-driven.” He further elaborated that he’s “always trying to recreate an emotion and a feeling that resonates in the streets.”

Pusha has an intricate style of rhyming, typically coupling up to four bars together with dense wordplay. His delivery was faster and sharper in his Clipse days since he only ever rapped 16 bars. Once he went solo, Pusha’s delivery changed significantly. His favorite rappers are The Notorious B.I.G. and Big Daddy Kane who he cites as influences – and has a knack of working with the industry’s best producers. Collaborators include: The Neptunes, Kanye West, The-Dream, Nottz, DJ Don Cannon and Hudson Mohawke. As his solo career progressed, Pusha’s unique ability to rap over unorthodox beats allowed him to work in electronic music. See Hudson Mohawke’s “Chimes Remix” and Yogi’s “Burial.”

King Push spoke to Genius and broke down some of his classic lines, including his famous “yuugh” ad-lib.

songs.full_title: The Story of Adidon by Pusha T
songs.title: The Story of Adidon

description.plain:
“The Story of Adidon” is Pusha-T’s response to Drake’s diss track “Duppy Freestyle.” Inspired by the title, and borrowing the instrumental from JAY-Z’s “The Story of O.J.,” Pusha sets aside topics of his beef with Drake so far, and instead focuses on Drake’s character and personal relationships.

He claims Drake had a baby with a pornstar, allegedly called “Adonis,” which also lends the track its name – a portmanteau of “Adonis” and “Adidas.” Pusha also attacks Drake’s close associates like his mother Sandi Graham, father Dennis, label-boss Birdman and OVO producer Noah “40” Shebib.

The song’s artwork is a picture of Drake in blackface and was taken by photographer David Leyes, which previously appeared on Leyes’s website in his gallery. The portraits were removed as of May 30, 2018, but the portrait chosen for the album cover can still be found via an archived version of the gallery page, with an additional portrait from the same shoot also archived.

Drake responded to the frenzy caused by the photo and explained the backstory in an Instagram post.

In October 2018, following an interview in which Drake suggested that the information about his hidden child came from Kanye West, Pusha went on the Joe Budden Podcast to reveal that it indirectly came from Drake’s producer, OVO 40:

The information came from 40. It didn’t come from Kanye, at all.  40 is sleeping with a woman who begins to, he talks to her daily, five, six hours a day… With that also came the fact that Drake has a child

songs.full_title: Nosetalgia by Pusha T (Ft. Kendrick Lamar)
songs.title: Nosetalgia

description.plain:
This track illustrates the balance of the drug game. On one side you have Pusha T who’s sold cocaine half his life and on the other you have Kendrick Lamar, the kid who had to watch his father sniff it during the 80’s crack epidemic.

The song’s title is a pun on nose+nostalgia, and offers a perspective of looking back at a childhood growing up around cocaine. Scent is also the sense most closely linked to memory, and both verse include distinct references to smells.

songs.full_title: Infrared by Pusha T
songs.title: Infrared

description.plain:
Infrared light is light that is usually invisible to human eyes, but using special kinds of film or devices, you can see things you wouldn’t usually see.

In this way, Pusha T can see that a lot of rappers aren’t real, specifically Drake, who he calls out for having ghostwriters and references subliminally throughout the track. The two rappers have beefed years ago, trading shots at each other on tracks like “Exodus 23:1” and “Two Birds, One Stone.” With “Infrared,” Push seems to reignite the beef.

On Friday, May 25, 2018, Drake responded to this diss track, “Infrared,” with a diss track of his own called “Duppy Freestyle.” Drizzy sent shots at both Pusha T and Kanye West.

Must’ve had your infrared wrong, now your head on the beam

However, Push would release his own response to “Duppy Freestyle” four days later, titled “The Story of Adidon.”

songs.full_title: Exodus 23:1 by Pusha T (Ft. The-Dream)
songs.title: Exodus 23:1

description.plain:
Thou shalt not raise a false report: put not thine hand with the wicked to be an unrighteous witness.

—Exodus 23:1

Paralleling Biggie’s “What’s Beef?,” Pusha separates the true thugs from the fakes.

Although Pusha unconvincingly denies speculations that this song is a Lil Wayne/YMCMB diss, multiple lines seem to be aimed at Drake and Wayne.

Whether or not this song was aimed at YMCMB, Wayne sent out this tweet soon after the tracks release:

https://twitter.com/LilTunechi/status/205582116895997953

Pusha has his fellow label mates on his side, though:

https://twitter.com/wizardcud/status/205765597030658048

songs.full_title: What Would Meek Do? by Pusha T (Ft. Kanye West)
songs.title: What Would Meek Do?
songs.title_with_featured: What Would Meek Do? (Ft. Kanye West)

description.plain:
Originally titled “How Do You Respond,” the sixth track of DAYTONA finds Pusha T and Kanye West responding to their haters.

Pusha lays a braggadocious verse about being among the “Top Five” in the game and “letting the jewels […] talk,” while also hinting at his past life as a drug dealer. Throughout the track, Push makes reference to Meek Mill’s 2017 incarceration.

Kanye’s verse finds him responding to backlash from a spree of controversial comments regarding MAGA and Donald Trump.

songs.full_title: Drug Dealers Anonymous by Pusha T (Ft. JAY-Z)
songs.title: Drug Dealers Anonymous

description.plain:
On “Drug Dealers Anonymous,” Pusha T and Jay Z deliver two stellar verses over an eerie DJ Dahi beat. Both MC’s heavily reference their former days as drug dealers and spit autobiographical bars—Push refers to donating to Flint, Michigan during the 2016 water crisis, while Jay takes us back in time to Jaz-O’s Word To the Jaz 1989 tour of London.

Separating the verses is a sample of The Blaze reporter Tomi Lahren from her show Tomi. Lahren spoke negatively about Beyoncé’s provocative halftime show at Super Bowl 50, using Jay’s drug dealing past to criticize Bey. Lahren took to Twitter to thank Hov and Pusha for the use of her voice clip.

This song is the first time either artist has featured on the others song. The pair first collaborated on Kanye West’s 2010 posse cut “So Appalled.”

Hova’s music has played a pivotal part in Push’s career—as evident by frequent mentions:


Best d-boy all I’m missing is a dash
Difference between me and Hova
—“King Push”

Sold more dope than the old Jigga
Now niggas calling me the new Hov
—“No Flex Zone (Remix)”


The two have many things in common: heavy affiliation with Kanye and Pharrell, Drake subliminals, and, as made obvious by “Drug Dealers Anonymous,” an abundance of drug references in their music.

songs.full_title: Numbers on the Boards by Pusha T
songs.title: Numbers on the Boards

description.plain:
“Numbers on the Boards” was the second single from My Name Is My Name. This intense, wordplay-dense track is a fan-favorite from MNIMN. Push says he wanted it to sound like a “street record.” Rolling Stone rated the single 4 out of 5 stars.

This song was for the fans, Push says, “I wanted it to sound like a mixtape—just that un-compromised rap feel. It’s what that [rap] purist loves. I think they spoke out loud when I dropped it. It’s a monster.”

Pusha told MTV News that Kanye West, who produced the song, dropped it spontaneously on May 10th, without his label’s permission:

Ye just called me and said, “Man, I’m gonna send you this record. And I called him back and told him it was crazy. He told me, "I'mma put it out in 15 minutes.” I asked him, “Did you call the label?” Because we leak records all the time, we lie, we say we don’t know how it happened, we got hacked, and it’s always such a big issue. So I asked if he called them and Kanye said, “No, I didn’t call them and I’m putting it out in 15 minutes.” So, it dropped, man.

The minimalistic cover art was designed by Kanye during the video shoot for the music video:


That was the beginning of the minimal wave that we got on. We thought that song was so dynamic, a song where we had to implement these design ideas.

There was the video going around when we put the song out, I was going crazy and talking to Ye on the phone when I first heard the final version of [“Numbers on the Boards”]. I was screaming at the top of my lungs. He asked me what I was gonna wear when we shot the video, and I screamed at him, “This is about drugs and black T-shirts! This is not about fashion.” That turned into another conversation—Then what’s the artwork? He was like, “there’s no artwork.” That was the extreme theme, and our first way of implementing what we were discussing about the stark and minimal, art where the primary focus is on the music.


—Pusha T, Interview with The Fader

“Who I Am” was released with a similar album cover that reads, “No Artwork 2.”, while a “No Artwork 3” would come along with Kanye West’s 2016 posse cut “Champions.”

That was the beginning of the minimal wave that we got on. We thought that song was so dynamic, a song where we had to implement these design ideas.

There was the video going around when we put the song out, I was going crazy and talking to Ye on the phone when I first heard the final version of [“Numbers on the Boards”]. I was screaming at the top of my lungs. He asked me what I was gonna wear when we shot the video, and I screamed at him, “This is about drugs and black T-shirts! This is not about fashion.” That turned into another conversation—Then what’s the artwork? He was like, “there’s no artwork.” That was the extreme theme, and our first way of implementing what we were discussing about the stark and minimal, art where the primary focus is on the music.


—Pusha T, Interview with The Fader

“Who I Am” was released with a similar album cover that reads, “No Artwork 2.”, while a “No Artwork 3” would come along with Kanye West’s 2016 posse cut “Champions.”

songs.full_title: If You Know You Know by Pusha T
songs.title: If You Know You Know

description.plain:
On the opening track of his 2018 album, DAYTONA, Pusha T touches on a subject that he has been talking about most of his career: crack/cocaine. King Push brags about how he is on top of the trap game. He was once a cocaine dealer after all.

The phrase “If You Know You Know” relates to anyone who has gone down the similar path to the “Drug Dealing” lifestyle as Pusha T.

The song is littered with references to the drug activities of Push and his associates, which in 2009 became the subject of a federal indictment and led to the imprisonment of at least seven of Push’s associates, including one-time Clipse manager Anthony “Tony” Gonzales, who was sentenced to 32 years in federal prison.

songs.full_title: Trouble on My Mind by Pusha T (Ft. Tyler, The Creator)
songs.title: Trouble on My Mind
songs.title_with_featured: Trouble on My Mind (Ft. Tyler, The Creator)

description.plain:
“Trouble on My Mind” is the lead single to Pusha T’s EP, Fear of God II: Let Us Pray. Produced by The Neptunes, the track was debuted on July 8, 2011, alongside its music video through RedBull, without Pusha T’s consent.

The song went on to be one of Push’s most popular records, even scoring a place on the 2012 record-breaking comedy, Project X’s soundtrack. Pusha T dedicated the collaboration to “the critics who doubted the chemistry.”

songs.full_title: Santeria by Pusha T
songs.title: Santeria

description.plain:
On “Santeria,” Push discusses the tragic murder of his friend and road manager De'Von “Day Day” Pickett. Santería—“The Way of the Saints”—is a Yoruba religion that uses mediums and divination to communicate to spirits and deities.  To cope with the pain, Push speaks to the spirit of his friend De'Von sharing his battles of vengeance and distress over what sadly happened.

Also, note that Pusha ironically dedicates the song “Santeria” to his manager whom Push described as always being in church.

songs.full_title: Neck & Wrist by Pusha T (Ft. JAY-Z & Pharrell Williams)
songs.title: Neck & Wrist

description.plain:
Pusha T and JAY-Z reunite for a third time on “Neck & Wrist,” the third single for Pusha’s fourth studio album, It’s Almost Dry.  On the cut, the ‘cocaine rap’ legends reflect on the state of their luxurious lives and long careers, while imitating 50 Cent’s vocal inflections from his 2005 hit single, “Window Shopper,” over Pharrell Williams' drum-heavy production.

On February 21, 2022, Steven Victor, Pusha T’s manager, previewed a short snippet of JAY-Z’s verse on the song via Instagram. Pusha T first teased the collaboration on a tweet dating back to February 8, 2022, and later confirmed it on a February 20 interview with Million Dollaz Worth Of Game.

Push announced the single’s release on April 5, teasing lyrics from Hov’s verse, revealing the single’s artwork and Pharrell’s involvement.

songs.full_title: Hard Piano by Pusha T (Ft. Rick Ross)
songs.title: Hard Piano

description.plain:
King Push is joined by Maybach Music’s lead MC, Rick Ross, to discuss the woes and blessings that come with success—all over Ye’s hard-tinged piano beat.

The title of the song is a double entendre referencing the piano throughout the production and cocaine (piano keys; keys of cocaine) as well as ‘hard’ being one of the many names name for cocaine.

Similar to their 2013 collaboration on Push’s “Hold On,” this song contains a reflective message from both emcees about their previous endeavors with selling cocaine, troubles with the law, and how they’ve arose to the top of the music industry.

Production-wise, the “High as Apple Pie (Slice II)” sample was famously used at the end of Madlib-character Quasimoto’s “Real Eyes.” Kanye has expressed his appreciation of Madlib before, so it’s not surprising that he played with a sample that Madlib has used in the past. The two producers have also worked together—“No More Parties in LA.”

songs.full_title: Untouchable by Pusha T
songs.title: Untouchable

description.plain:
Like he did on “Numbers on the Boards,” Pusha T drops two menacing verses accompanied by a 90’s sample.

The hook is a vocal sample from The Notorious B.I.G.’s verse on Pudgee’s 1995 single “Think Big.” Earlier in 2015, Pusha  went on record with Rolling Stone stating Biggie was the greatest rapper who’s ever lived:

I believe the Notorious B.I.G. was the greatest rapper who’s ever lived. I remember in ‘94, when Ready to Die came out, I was in 11th grade, living in my mother’s house in Virginia. There was a frenzy at my high school, arguing and talking about that album. We used to spend hours in the car, reciting his raps, trying to figure out what in the hell made him veer off in this way or that way. Some rappers just say a punchline, and it’s like, “OK, we get it.” But Big delved deep. He was a master painter with words. And his flow was just so effortless. I mean, I think I’m an awesome writer, but my bars still sound like bars. Big had all these intricacies, all these colors, all these witty things – and it didn’t sound like a rap. It was a conversation.

songs.full_title: Hold On by Pusha T (Ft. Rick Ross)
songs.title: Hold On

description.plain:
On “Hold On,” Pusha T and Rick Ross offer their verses as encouragement for people in disenfranchised environments who have to survive by hustling on the streets—both legally and illegally.

Throughout Pusha T’s verse, he asserts his credibility by mentioning his previous habit of selling cocaine and how he continues to hustle with the same mentality through his music. He also references the systemic injustice that many Black people face in America. Despite enduring the struggles of being a Black man in America, Pusha rose up to become one of the most successful hip hop artists of all time. He hopes that his life may be used as motivation.

Throughout Ross’s verse, he reminisces on what his life was like as a child growing up in the hood. Just like Push in the first verse, Ross also uses his swaggering punchlines and metaphors as motivation for young people trying to make it out of their impoverished conditions.

songs.full_title: Diet Coke by Pusha T
songs.title: Diet Coke

description.plain:
“Diet Coke” is the lead single for Pusha T’s fourth studio album, It’s Almost Dry. It was first previewed after a snippet surfaced of Push and Kanye West recording a music video. It was later confirmed that Ye was involved in the song after his then-girlfriend Julia Fox told Interview Magazine that she had gone to a music video shoot for the collaboration. Push later shared a snippet of the song at an afterparty for the KENZO fashion show in Paris, France.

The beat, originally intended to be an interlude for 88-Keys beat tape, The Makings of Crack Cocaine, was produced in 2004, around 18 years before “Diet Coke” was released.

songs.full_title: Dreamin Of The Past by Pusha T (Ft. Kanye West)
songs.title: Dreamin Of The Past
songs.title_with_featured: Dreamin Of The Past (Ft. Kanye West)

description.plain:
On “Dreamin Of The Past,” Pusha T and Kanye both reminisce over luxurious moments from their life that past versions of themselves never thought they would experience. The title comes from a line in the first verse of the track’s sample, Donny Hathaway’s 1972 cover of John Lennon’s 1971 song “Jealous Guy.”

Push’s manager, Steven Victor first previewed this track on his Instagram while at the afterparty of the KENZO Paris show, on January 23, 2022. Days later, Upscale Vandal, a close friend and business associate of Push, shared another short snippet via Instagram, teasing the song’s release.

On April 11, 2022, Push talked about the collaboration in an interview with Charlemagne, where he revealed Kanye West originally produced this beat for his August 2021 album Donda but Push liked it so much, he “begged” for it, that Ye has a brief appearance on the song and the song’s title. The track also appeared on an early version of the track list for Donda.

songs.full_title: M.P.A. by Pusha T (Ft. A$AP Rocky, Kanye West & The-Dream)
songs.title: M.P.A.
songs.title_with_featured: M.P.A. (Ft. A$AP Rocky, Kanye West & The-Dream)

description.plain:
Kanye and Pusha T collaborate once again on “M.P.A.,” an acronym for Money, Pussy, Alcohol. On the set of the video, Push explained that the song “sort of describes my perspective on life,” adding that M, P, and A are:

The three vices that I feel like sway people in the world today and sway people in the life, especially in the street life.

A$AP Rocky—with whom Push has worked before on the track “TKO (Black Friday Remix)”—compared this song to his own acronym-titled, “PMW (All I Really Need)” [off LONG.LIVE.A$AP].

It’s all the same kind of content. It’s just talking about most of us rappers’ vices. So, I could relate to it.”



Kanye West and J. Cole produced the track. Cole flipped the beat for the third verse, because Pusha wanted a “darker” tone.

The song is built off a sample of “Konklusjon” (Norwegian for “conclusion”) written by Finn Pedersen, and played by the Norwegian Christian band Good News.

 https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NMLChIR7YNQ

The underlying chain sound is reminiscent of Kanye West’s “Jesus Walks”. The sound is used to represents vices to which we are bound.

check out its sheet music!

songs.full_title: M.F.T.R. by Pusha T (Ft. The-Dream)
songs.title: M.F.T.R.

description.plain:
“M.F.T.R” stands for More Famous Than Rich. Pusha spoke with Billboard Magazine and explained the inspiration behind the title:

When you look at society, it’s like a big masquerade even through social media. I’m from a time, an era and a lifestyle where you can’t really speak on it without really having it. To be more famous than rich seems to be a thing that’s going on right now and I’m not into that.

Pusha spoke about this in more detail during an interview with Apple Music’s Zane Lowe, saying  that the song was for all the people that don’t really have money but are still showing off on Instagram.

You can listen to the interview here:
https://itunes.apple.com/us/post/idsa.4939e334-9dda-11e5-a49a-a7f4abc93a5e

There seems to be a few shots at the Cash Money family, especially Lil Wayne, Drake, and the rest of Wayne’s Young Money label too. Despite their fame, the rappers haven’t seen the proceeds from their album sales, while Birdman has gotten rich at them. Pusha’s been speaking on that label situation for years, most notably on “Exodus 23:1”, and dropped another line about it on “Untouchable”, the first single from this album.

The track features R&B singer The-Dream, who also provided soulful vocals on “40 Acres” from My Name is My Name.

“M.F.T.R.” premiered on Beats 1 Radio exclusively, listen here:

https://itunes.apple.com/us/post/idsa.747d2652-9dd2-11e5-aa7e-be3f76ed9489

songs.full_title: Millions by Pusha T (Ft. Rick Ross)
songs.title: Millions

description.plain: “Millions” is the second single off of Pusha T’s long-awaited mixtape Wrath of Caine. Pusha recruits Rick Ross for the hard track about making millions, how they came up, and how their hoods are still apart of them. The track is aided by production from Pusha’s label exec, Kanye West and 808 Mafia’s Southside.

description.plain:
This song represents an allusion to JAY-Z’s “A Week Ago” from Vol. 2 Hard Knock Life about how once friends are as Jay said it, now “dropping names” and how rats are trying to save themselves by breaking vows and codes they agreed upon by entering the drug game.

songs.full_title: Rock N Roll by Pusha T (Ft. Kanye West & Kid Cudi)
songs.title: Rock N Roll
songs.title_with_featured: Rock N Roll (Ft. Kanye West & Kid Cudi)

description.plain:
Pusha T recruits ex-G.O.O.D. Music collaborators, Kanye West and Kid Cudi for “Rock N Roll.” The artists, who previously collaborated on “Feel the Love,” take up an old-school gangsta rap flow while rapping about drugs, family, and the value of their time. The song features Ye’s emblematic sample-heavy production combined with Pharrell Williams drums.

After the song, together with the rest of the album, leaked four days before its release, it garnered a lot of attention due to the fact that it was just two months following the online beef between the KIDS SEE GHOSTS duo.

Cudi, however, quickly cleared the situation up by tweeting about how “Rock N Roll” was recorded before their falling out and it being the last song they would appear on together.

songs.full_title: Brambleton by Pusha T
songs.title: Brambleton

description.plain:
In an April 11, 2022 interview with Charlamagne tha God, Pusha T revealed “Brambleton,” a deep cut from IT’S ALMOST DRY. It was described as a “very personal record.”

In the song, Push addresses his relationship with his former manager, Anthony ‘Geezy’ Gonzales, and how he felt after watching the latter’s infamous March 2020 VladTV interview, where he talked about managing Clipse—Pusha T and No Malice’s duo, the song “S.N.I.T.C.H.” and his drug-dealing past.

The title comes from Brambleton, a street in Norfolk, Virginia, where Push’s late mother used to work as a pharmacist technician during his early life.

songs.full_title: Let Me Love You by Pusha T (Ft. Kelly Rowland)
songs.title: Let Me Love You
songs.title_with_featured: Let Me Love You (Ft. Kelly Rowland)

description.plain:
The song is about Pusha cheating on his girl with a “side chick”. Kelly Rowland’s part is from the perspective of a “side chick” who doesn’t care that what she’s doing is wrong, she’s proud to be messing with a star.

Pusha also pays homage to Ma$e by using a similar flow and inflection to the ones Ma$e used on Harlem World.

Pusha T wanted this song to blow up and be a single for his album, but it didn’t. He later revealed in his interview on the 188th episode of the Joe Budden Podcast in 2018.

songs.full_title: Who I Am by Pusha T (Ft. 2 Chainz & Big Sean)
songs.title: Who I Am
songs.title_with_featured: Who I Am (Ft. 2 Chainz & Big Sean)

description.plain:
Pusha T recruits Big Sean and 2 Chainz to rap on verses flexing why they’re in the spot that they’re in. Pusha T has his common drug dealer approach to the track, 2 Chainz speaks on all the women he can get on the daily, and Big Sean talks on his girlfriend at the time, Naya Rivera, as well as repping G.O.O.D. Music which Push and Sean are both members of.

Pusha T talked about the album and his drug talk in an interview on Sway In The Morning

My Name Is My Name, I titled the album that because I said “Man I’ve been over here for 10 years now” – You know what I’m about, my name is Pusha T, my first record ever on Electra when I got dropped was “I got caught dealing” at the age of 15.

songs.title: Doesn’t Matter

description.plain: Doesn’t Matter was released on Pusha T’s Wrath of Caine mixtape in January, 2013.  The song responds to some of the criticisms he’s received since starting his solo career.  Push also uses this platform to send shots at the YMCMB crew, continuing the beef that had previously reached a boiling point with Pusha’s Exodus 23:1 and Lil Wayne’s response, Goulish (Pusha T Diss).

songs.full_title: I Pray For You by Pusha T (Ft. Clipse, Labrinth & No Malice)
songs.title: I Pray For You
songs.title_with_featured: I Pray For You (Ft. Clipse, Labrinth & No Malice)

description.plain:
Pusha’s favourite song off the album, “I Pray For You” is the fourth Clipse collaboration since the group ended in 2010, and the second in the past month. This is also the first track where No Malice has referred to himself as Malice since his conversion to Christianity in 2012.

Pusha T raps about what he has accomplished with his brother in their lives and careers, while Malice turns faith talk into some threats living up to his name, all over Labrinth’s gospel-like vocals and organ-heavy production reminiscent of church music.

The song was first revealed in Pusha T’s April 11, 2022 interview with Charlamagne tha God and it was later used for the album’s date announcement in a short trailer.

Before presenting us the good life they currently have, they take us through the times they had to hustle on the streets. Despite the ups-and-downs and consequences that came with the life they chose, they stand tall with no regrets.

songs.full_title: Call My Bluff by Pusha T
songs.title: Call My Bluff

description.plain:
The song “Call My Bluff” was produced by Pharrell Williams as part of Pusha T’s 2022 “It’s Almost Dry” album.

Push is known as G.O.O.D. Music label’s “hitter”, meaning the track could be a metaphor for how swiftly Pusha T can respond to a sneak diss; and by sending goons and thugs.

The track is possibly a response to Drake; shortly before the release of the album, a Jack Harlow song featuring Drake was leaked. In the leaked song, Drake makes multiple sneak disses towards Pusha T:

My urges for revenge are uncontrollable
I know we’re gettin’ older though, yeah
But I gotta get a nigga back for that
It’s non-negotiable, it’s not even debatable

It’s well known that Pusha T landed a huge victory against Drake in 2018 with a devastating diss track.

Pusha T’s infamous The story of Adidon was known for leaking private information about Drake and using it against him, most notably Drake conceiving a child with a Pornstar Sophie Brussaux and allegedly not taking care of the child.

All I hear is plug talk comin’ from middleman
All I hear is tall tales comin’ from little men

This is the second sneak diss towards Pusha T as it’s well known to most hiphop fans that Pusha T’s music is centered around his past as a drug dealer.

If I see ya’, I spit in ya’ faces, ha-tu
Daytonas with the green faces

This is the final confirmation that the Drake verse is a diss to Pusha T, as the line references Daytona, a watch which is also the name of Pusha T’s most critically acclaimed and beloved solo album.

Due to the context at the time of the release, the song is likely Pusha T warning Drake; if he keeps sneak dissing and thinking Pusha T is bluffing, he will respond by leaking even more private information.

At the time of “The Story of Adidon”’s release, it was believed that Push had even more information that would be leaked in future diss tracks should Drake respond, as was referenced at the end of the diss track:
“We gon' take this slow
We just gon' peel it back layer-by-layer”.

However, this is just speculation, as Pusha T himself said in an interview that he didn’t feel that he should respond as he thought the leaked song was old and underwhelming since Drake was only sneak dissing after Pusha T had already landed major hits to Drake and had gone past sneak disses.

songs.full_title: Crutches, Crosses, Caskets by Pusha T
songs.title: Crutches, Crosses, Caskets

description.plain:
“CCC” stands for “crutches, cross, caskets.” Push told Genius: “I feel like “Crutches, Crosses, Caskets” is my interpretation of the rap game. The catch phrase in the hook is “all I see is victims.”

He also spoke with Mikey T The Movie Star at Art Basal Miami about the record:

Man, I got a record out there called ‘Crutches, Crosses, Caskets’ and it’s like.. it’s just one of the hardest records – “hardest”, but not even overtly hard. It’s a conversation. It’s a conversation and it’s just.. eerie and it’s just true and it’s just about, you know… all I see is victims.

This isn’t the first time Push and Bad Boy head/hip hop mogul Puff Daddy have collaborated. The pair linked up on “Changing Of The Guards.”

In a Reddit AMA, Pusha names this record as his favorite on the project.

This is a small clip from the studio session.

songs.title: Let The Smokers Shine The Coupes
songs.title_with_featured: Let The Smokers Shine The Coupes

description.plain:
Shaheem Reid, a veteran music journalist who attended the private listening session for It’s Almost Dry, revealed “Let The Smokers Shine The Coupes” in an Instagram post.

After calling it one of his early favorite songs, Shaheem wrote that Push told Pharrell Williams to take inspiration from the RZA produced Raekwon’s 1995 classic cut, “Glaciers of Ice.”
